newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Gujral sees ominous signs for agriculture.
newsitem.headline: India's Gujral sees ominous signs for agriculture.

text.p: Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said on Saturday that he was worried agricultural productivity was languishing, and urged the development of new seeds and dry farming to ensure a healthy farm sector.

"Agriculture is an important sector. There are some reasons to be satisfied about it, but there are many reasons not to be satisfied about it," he told a business conference organised by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII).

"I think productivity is now causing anxiety....I see the ominous signs (of productivity), I hate, I hesitate to use the word, coming towards a halt. And if that halt comes, we'll be in difficulty," he said.
"Therefore I have told the agriculture universities, specially their research and development departments, that they must emphasise a great deal on finding new seeds," Gujral said.
India's oilseeds production had been stagnant since 1993/94 (July-June), with an annual output of about 22 million tonnes harvested from an area of about 26 million hectares.
The per-hectare yield of rice declined in 1995/96 (July-June) to 1,855 kg from 1,911 in the previous crop year. Wheat yield fell to 2,493 kg per hectare from 2,559 kg.
The conference was organised to mark the 50th anniversary of India's independence from Britain.
He said water availability was becoming a problem and increased efforts were needed to develop new technologies for farming with less water.
"Our research and development must aim towards dry farming," Gujral said. "As water problem continues, we have to think of new technologies."
India, under an economic reforms programme initiated in 1991, removed state controls on most sectors, but controls continue to exist in many areas of the agriculture sector.

Finance Minister P. Chidambaram told the same conference that agriculture was one on the most over-regulated sectors and urged industry to support a special emphasis this year to remove controls over prices, trade and exports.
"Agriculture is perhaps the most over-regulated sector in India's economy," Chidambaram said.

"We don't allow free movement of foodgrains and other agriculture products. We don't allow consolidation of holdings (of land). We don't allow corporatisation of any part of agriculture," Chidambaram said.
He said India's farmers were not getting proper credit facilities. "They are also not allowed to raise credit from abroad even if they have the repaying capability," he said.
"We are talking about removing controls on industry," Chidambaram said. "Why are we not talking of removing controls on agriculture?
